In 1981 astronomer Robert Kirshner made a
shocking intergalactic discovery. 700 million

8.text:

barren sphere known as the Bootes Void. Its

15.text:

the universe and its origins.

The Void is at least ten times larger than
the rules of modern physics say is reasonably

26.text:
likely. As a structure, the Void verges on
the impossible.

with Nikolai Kardashev’s 1962 theory of

48.text:
A void is a massive region of space that holds
either minimal or no galaxies. They are created

55.text:
when mass collapses, and is followed by subatomic
particle implosions.

60.text:
With a diameter of 330 million light years,
the Bootes Void makes up 0.27% of the observable

69.text:
universe. But according to established scientific
understanding its huge size is impossible.

76.text:
The Big Bang theory states that the universe
is 14 billion years old, and that it has been

81.text:
expanding exponentially since its birth. Given
the age of the universe, there has only been

87.text:
enough time for voids to form that are tens
of millions of light years across, not hundreds.

95.text:
Stranger still, is just how empty the Bootes
Void is. It contains only 60 galaxies, around

102.text:
10,000 fewer than we should expect to find
in such a vast expanse.

107.text:
Many believe this means the void is the first
observable proof of a Kardashev scale III

116.text:
In 1964 Nikolai Kardashev - now Deputy Director
of Russia’s Astro Space Centre - published

122.text:
his theory for extra terrestrial development,
arguing that civilizations develop in 4 stages.

131.text:
A civilization reaches the third phase when
it becomes so technologically advanced that

137.text:
it is able to convert starlight into usable
energy. At this point, the species is able

143.text:
to replicate itself at astonishing rates,
spreading out across the universe and colonizing

149.text:
galaxies. Many consider this is a necessary
step for any civilization to avoid extinction.

156.text:
Could this explain the Void’s chilling dearth
of stars?

160.text:
In 1960 theoretical physicist Freeman Dyson
published “Search for Artificial Stellar

165.text:
Sources of Infrared Radiation”. This paper
suggests that in order to harness the energy

167.text:
from stars, civilizations must construct huge
artificial structures around them, essentially

173.text:
masking them from the outside. It is possible
that networks of interlinked “Dyson’s

181.text:
shells” are distorting the appearance of
the Void, and what lies within it.

186.text:
A further mystery is the almost perfectly
spherical shape of the Void. It is what space

191.text:
blogger Michael Anissimov has called “the
most perfectly shaped vacuum in space”.

192.text:
Could this be the result of an extraordinary
piece of intergalactic engineering?

In 2015 astronomers at the University of Hawaii
identified another “supervoid”, which,

István Szapudi described as “the largest

239.text:
Scientist Greg Aldering points out that the
galaxies within the Bootes Void are in a very

244.text:
clear “tube” formation. He argues that
given how unlikely this alignment is, it is

250.text:
highly probable the Void was formed from smaller
voids colliding and merging with each other.

256.text:
The tubular arrangement is therefore what
remains of the boundaries between smaller

261.text:
voids. While science has not yet been able
to confirm this, NASA has publicly discussed

267.text:
this theory, suggesting that it has the gravitas
that other ideas do not.

272.text:
Significantly, while the Void is perplexing,
it is consistent with the Lambda-CDM model

278.text:
of cosmological evolution. This means that
although it diverges from the standard model

283.text:
of the Big Bang Theory, scientists do not
consider the variations great enough to undermine

290.text:
existing knowledge about our universe and
its past.

293.text:
The only thing the Bootes Void offers proof
for, is the mystifying nature of the cosmos.
